fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a category with sufficient structure and \Gamma = x_{1} \colon B_{1} , \ldots , x_{m} \colon B_{m} be a context over a signature \Sigma. Given a \Sigma-structure M in \mathcal { C }, the interpretation of a term-in-context \Gamma .t of sort B in M is a morphism { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma .t \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } \colon M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m}) \to MB defined recursively on the structure of t as follow:

fr:ul.fr:li: { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma .x_{i} \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } is the i-th projection \pi _{i} \colon M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m}) \to MB_{i}.

If f \colon A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} \to B is a function symbol and t_{1}, \ldots ,t_{n} are terms of appropriate sorts then { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma .f(t_{1}, \ldots ,t_{n}) \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } is the composite M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m}) \xrightarrow { ( { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma .t_{1} \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } , \ldots , { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma .t_{n} \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } ) } M(A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n}) \xrightarrow { Mf } MB

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a category with finite products and \Sigma be a signature. The category of \Sigma-structures in \mathcal { C }, denoted as \Sigma \text {-} \mathsf {Str} ( \mathcal { C } ), consists of the following data:

html:tr.html:td:
A \Sigma-structure consists of the following data:
Each sort A in \Sigma is associated with an object MA in \mathcal { C }. This is extended to any finite string of sorts by the assignment M(A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n}) \mapsto MA_{1} \times \cdots \times MA_{n}. The empty string is associated with the terminal object 1 of \mathcal { C }.
Each function symbol f \colon A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} \to B is associated with a morphism Mf \colon M(A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n}) \to MB in \mathcal { C }.
Each relation symbol R \rightarrowtail A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} is associated with a subobject of M(A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n}) in \mathcal { C }.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Composition and identities are defined componentwise from those in \mathcal { C }.
Let \Sigma be a signature. The collection of (raw) terms over \Sigma is inductively generated by the following rules:

fr:ul.fr:li: Each variable x of sort A is a term of sort A.

Let us write t \colon A if t is a term of sort A. If f \colon A_{1}, \ldots ,A_{n} \to B is a function symbol and t_{1} \colon A_{1} , \ldots , t_{n} \colon A_{n} are terms of corresponding sorts, then f(t_{1}, \ldots ,t_{n}) \colon B.
